module.name: init
module.summary: System initialization programs (init and init scripts).

interface.name: init_mountpoint
interface.summary: Make the specified type usable as a mountpoint.
interface.desc: Make the specified type usable as a mountpoint. This is normally used for systemd BindPaths options.

param.name: file_type
param.summary: Type to be used as a mountpoint.

interface.name: init_path_unit_location_file
interface.summary: Create a file type monitored by a systemd path unit.

param.name: script_file
param.summary: Type to be used for a path unit monitored location.

interface.name: init_script_file
interface.summary: Create a file type used for init scripts.

desc.p: Create a file type used for init scripts. It can not be used in conjunction with init_script_domain(). These script files are typically stored in the /etc/init.d directory.

Typically this is used to constrain what services an admin can start/stop. For example, a policy writer may want to constrain a web administrator to only being able to restart the web server, not other services. This special type will help address that goal.
This also makes the type usable for files; thus an explicit call to files_type() is redundant.

param.name: script_file
param.summary: Type to be used for a script file.

interface.name: init_unit_file
interface.summary: Make the specified type usable for systemd unit files.

param.name: type
param.summary: Type to be used for systemd unit files.

interface.name: init_script_domain
interface.summary: Create a domain used for init scripts.

desc.p: Create a domain used for init scripts. Can not be used in conjunction with init_script_file().

param.name: domain
param.summary: Type to be used as an init script domain.

param.name: script_file
param.summary: Type of the script file used as an entry point to this domain.

interface.name: init_domain
interface.summary: Create a domain which can be started by init.

param.name: domain
param.summary: Type to be used as a domain.

param.name: entry_point
param.summary: Type of the program to be used as an entry point to this domain.

interface.name: init_ranged_domain
interface.summary: Create a domain which can be started by init, with a range transition.

param.name: domain
param.summary: Type to be used as a domain.

param.name: entry_point
param.summary: Type of the program to be used as an entry point to this domain.

interface.name: init_spec_daemon_domain
interface.summary: Setup a domain which can be manually transitioned to from init.

desc.p: Create a domain used for systemd services where the SELinuxContext option is specified in the .service file. This allows for the manual transition from systemd into the new domain. This is used when automatic transitions won't work. Used for the case where the same binary is used for multiple target domains.

param.name: domain
param.summary: Type to be used as a domain.

param.name: entry_point
param.summary: Type of the program being executed when starting this domain.

interface.name: init_daemon_domain
interface.summary: Create a domain for long running processes (daemons/services) which are started by init scripts.

desc.p: Create a domain for long running processes (daemons/services) which are started by init scripts. Short running processes should use the init_system_domain() interface instead. Typically all long running processes started by an init script (usually in /etc/init.d) will need to use this interface.
The types will be made usable as a domain and file, making calls to domain_type() and files_type() redundant.
If the process must also run in a specific MLS/MCS level, the init_ranged_daemon_domain() should be used instead.

param.name: domain
param.summary: Type to be used as a daemon domain.

param.name: entry_point
param.summary: Type of the program to be used as an entry point to this domain.

interface.name: init_ranged_daemon_domain
interface.summary: Create a domain for long running processes (daemons/services) which are started by init scripts, running at a specified MLS/MCS range.

desc.p: Create a domain for long running processes (daemons/services) which are started by init scripts, running at a specified MLS/MCS range. Short running processes should use the init_ranged_system_domain() interface instead. Typically all long running processes started by an init script (usually in /etc/init.d) will need to use this interface if they need to run in a specific MLS/MCS range.
The types will be made usable as a domain and file, making calls to domain_type() and files_type() redundant.
If the policy build option TYPE is standard (MLS and MCS disabled), this interface has the same behavior as init_daemon_domain().

param.name: domain
param.summary: Type to be used as a daemon domain.

param.name: entry_point
param.summary: Type of the program to be used as an entry point to this domain.

interface.name: init_abstract_socket_activation
interface.summary: Abstract socket service activation (systemd).

param.name: domain
param.summary: The domain to be started by systemd socket activation.

interface.name: init_named_socket_activation
interface.summary: Named socket service activation (systemd).

param.name: domain
param.summary: The domain to be started by systemd socket activation.

interface.name: init_system_domain
interface.summary: Create a domain for short running processes which are started by init scripts.

desc.p: Create a domain for short running processes which are started by init scripts. These are generally applications that are used to initialize the system during boot. Long running processes, such as daemons/services should use the init_daemon_domain() interface instead. Typically all short running processes started by an init script (usually in /etc/init.d) will need to use this interface.
The types will be made usable as a domain and file, making calls to domain_type() and files_type() redundant.
If the process must also run in a specific MLS/MCS level, the init_ranged_system_domain() should be used instead.

param.name: domain
param.summary: Type to be used as a system domain.

param.name: entry_point
param.summary: Type of the program to be used as an entry point to this domain.

interface.name: init_ranged_system_domain
interface.summary: Create a domain for short running processes which are started by init scripts.

desc.p: Create a domain for long running processes (daemons/services) which are started by init scripts. These are generally applications that are used to initialize the system during boot. Long running processes should use the init_ranged_system_domain() interface instead. Typically all short running processes started by an init script (usually in /etc/init.d) will need to use this interface if they need to run in a specific MLS/MCS range.
The types will be made usable as a domain and file, making calls to domain_type() and files_type() redundant.
If the policy build option TYPE is standard (MLS and MCS disabled), this interface has the same behavior as init_system_domain().

param.name: domain
param.summary: Type to be used as a system domain.

param.name: entry_point
param.summary: Type of the program to be used as an entry point to this domain.

interface.summary: Execute init (/sbin/init) with a domain transition to the provided domain.

interface.name: init_exec_rc
interface.summary: Execute the rc application in the caller domain.

desc.p: This is only applicable to Gentoo or distributions that use the OpenRC init system.
The OpenRC /sbin/rc binary is used for both init scripts as well as management applications and tools. When used for management purposes, calling /sbin/rc should never cause a transition to initrc_t.

interface.name: init_getpgid
interface.summary: Get the process group of init.

interface.name: init_signal
interface.summary: Send init a generic signal.

interface.name: init_signull
interface.summary: Send init a null signal.

interface.name: init_sigchld
interface.summary: Send init a SIGCHLD signal.

interface.name: init_stream_connect
interface.summary: Connect to init with a unix socket.

interface.name: init_use_fds
interface.summary: Inherit and use file descriptors from init.

desc.p: Allow the specified domain to inherit file descriptors from the init program (process ID 1). Typically the only file descriptors to be inherited from init are for the console. This does not allow the domain any access to the object to which the file descriptors references.
Related interfaces:
Example usage:
init_use_fds(mydomain_t) term_use_console(mydomain_t)

Normally, processes that can inherit these file descriptors (usually services) write messages to the system log instead of writing to the console. Therefore, in many cases, this access should dontaudited instead.
Example dontaudit usage:
init_dontaudit_use_fds(mydomain_t) term_dontaudit_use_console(mydomain_t)

interface.name: init_dontaudit_use_fds
interface.summary: Do not audit attempts to inherit file descriptors from init.

interface.name: init_dgram_send
interface.summary: Send messages to init unix datagram sockets.

interface.name: init_rw_inherited_stream_socket

desc.p: Allow the specified domain to create an object in the general system log directories (e.g., /var/log) with a private type. Typically this is used for creating private log files in /var/log with the private type instead of the general system log type. To accomplish this goal, either the program must be SELinux-aware, or use this interface.
Related interfaces:
Example usage with a domain that can create and append to a private log file stored in the general directories (e.g., /var/log):

interface.name: logging_send_syslog_msg
interface.summary: Send system log messages.

desc.p: Allow the specified domain to connect to the system log service (syslog), to send messages be added to the system logs. Typically this is used by services that do not have their own log file in /var/log.
This does not allow messages to be sent to the auditing system.
Programs which use the libc function syslog() will require this access.

template.name: userdom_admin_user_template
template.summary: The template for creating an administrative user.

desc.p: This template creates a user domain, types, and rules for the user's tty, pty, home directories, tmp, and tmpfs files.

The privileges given to administrative users are:
Raw disk access
Set all sysctls
All kernel ring buffer controls
Create, read, write, and delete all files but shadow
Manage source and binary format SELinux policy
Run insmod

interface.name: userdom_use_user_ptys
interface.summary: Read and write a user domain pty.

interface.name: userdom_use_inherited_user_terminals
interface.summary: Read and write a user TTYs and PTYs.

desc.p: Allow the specified domain to read and write user TTYs and PTYs. This will allow the domain to interact with the user via the terminal. Typically all interactive applications will require this access.
However, this also allows the applications to spy on user sessions or inject information into the user session. Thus, this access should likely not be allowed for non-interactive domains.

interface.name: userdom_use_user_terminals
interface.summary: Read, write and open a user TTYs and PTYs.

desc.p: Allow the specified domain to read and write user TTYs and PTYs. This will allow the domain to interact with the user via the terminal. Typically all interactive applications will require this access.
This interface will also allow to open these user terminals, which should not be necessary in general and userdom_use_inherited_user_terminals() should be sufficient.
However, this also allows the applications to spy on user sessions or inject information into the user session. Thus, this access should likely not be allowed for non-interactive domains.

interface.name: userdom_dontaudit_use_user_terminals
interface.summary: Do not audit attempts to read and write a user domain tty and pty.

desc.p: Do not audit attempts to inherit the file descriptors from unprivileged user domains. This will suppress SELinux denial messages when the specified domain is denied the permission to inherit these file descriptors.

Allow w to display everyone
